sen.j: 石高（こくだか）とは、近世の日本において、土地の生産性を石 (単位)という単位で表したもの。
sen.e: "Kokudaka" refers to the figure of land productivity shown with stone (an unit), which was used in the early modern ages of Japan.
Kokudaka refers to the figure of land productivity shown with koku (a unit), which was used in the early modern ages of Japan.
Kokudaka refers to the figure of land productivity shown with koku (a unit), which was used in the early modern ages of Japan.

sen.j: 太閤検地以降、地租改正まで石高に応じた課税が行われた。
sen.e: Taxation on land was implemented according to kokudaka from the time of "Taiko-kenchi" (the land survey by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI) until the land-tax reform in the Meiji period.
Taxation on land was implemented according to kokudaka from the time of Taiko kenchi (the land survey by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI) until the land-tax reform in the Meiji period.
Taxation on land was implemented according to kokudaka from the time of Taiko kenchi (the land survey by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI) until the land-tax reform in the Meiji period.

sen.j: そこから転じて大名や旗本の収入も示した。
sen.e: And so, kokudaka also showed the income of "daimyo" (Japanese territorial lords) and that of "hatamoto" (direct retainers of 'bakufu' [Japanese feudal regime headed by a shogun]).
And so, kokudaka also showed the income of daimyo (Japanese territorial lords) and that of hatamoto (direct retainers of bakufu [Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun]).
sen.cmt: 統一リストに合わせました。
sen.e: And so, kokudaka also showed the income of daimyo (Japanese territorial lords) and that of hatamoto (direct retainers of bakufu [Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun]).

sen.j: 太閤検地以後江戸時代を通じて、田畑や屋敷などの土地の価値に至るまで、面積に石盛という一定の計数をかけて米の生産力に換算して石単位で表示するようになった。
sen.e: From the time of Taiko-kenchi until the end of the Edo period, the economic value of all kinds of land - from rice (or vegetable) field to residential area - was converted into the productivity of rice, and the productivity, whose unit was stone, was calculated by multiplying the land size by "kokumori" (land's productivity per 'tan' [a Japanese area unit]).
sen.cmt: （注①）原文はやや難解ですが、以下のような意味に推測して訳しています。下線部が翻訳者の修正・補充部分です。（「太閤検地以後江戸時代を通じて、田畑や屋敷に至るまで、あらゆる土地の経済的価値は、面積に石盛という・・・（以下原文に同じ）」）（注②）・・・「石盛」については「一反当たりの土地の生産性」と解説しています。
sen.e: From the time of Taiko kenchi through the Edo period, the economic value of all kinds of land such as rice (or vegetable) field and residential area, was converted into the productivity of rice, and the productivity, whose unit was koku, was calculated by multiplying the land size by a fixed figure called kokumori (land's productivity per 'tan' [a Japanese area unit]).

From the time of Taiko kenchi through the Edo period, the economic value of all kinds of land such as rice (or vegetable) field and residential area, was converted into the productivity of rice, and the productivity, whose unit was koku, was calculated by multiplying the land size by a fixed figure called kokumori (land's productivity per 'tan' [a Japanese area unit]).

sen.j: このような制度を石高制と言い、米以外の農作物や海産物の生産量も、米の生産量に換算されて表された。
sen.e: This was called "kokudaka system," and the output of crops (other than rice) and seafood was converted into the output of rice of the same economic value as those products.
sen.cmt: （注）原文の「米の生産量に換算されて表された。」の前に「同等の経済的価値を有する」と補って訳しています。
sen.e: This was called kokudaka system, and the output of crops other than rice and seafood was converted into the output of rice of the same economic value as those products.
This was called kokudaka system, and the output of crops other than rice and seafood was converted into the output of rice of the same economic value as those products.

sen.j: 大名をはじめとする武士の所領からの収入や俸禄を表す場合も石高を用いられた。
sen.e: Kokudaka was used to show the income of samurai (including daimyo) gained from their territory, and to show the retainers' salary given from the lord as well.
Kokudaka was used to show the income of samurai including daimyo gained from their territory, and to show the retainers' salary given from the lord as well.
Kokudaka was used to show the income of samurai including daimyo gained from their territory, and to show the retainers' salary given from the lord as well.

sen.j: 特に領民の場合には「百姓高所持」、武士（特に大名）の場合には「石高知行制」と称されることがある。
sen.e: Kokudaka system is sometimes called "hyakusho takashoji" (system to measure the property of a farmer with kokudaka) when mentioned for the farmer, or called "kokudaka chigyo system" (system to measure the annual stipend of a samurai with kokudaka) when mentioned for samurai (especially daimyo).

Kokudaka system is sometimes called 'hyakusho takashoji' (system to measure the property of a farmer with kokudaka) when mentioned for the farmer, or called 'kokudaka chigyo system' (system to measure the annual stipend of a samurai with kokudaka) when mentioned for samurai (especially daimyo).

Kokudaka system is sometimes called 'hyakusho takashoji' (system to measure the property of a farmer with kokudaka) when mentioned for the farmer, or called 'kokudaka chigyo system' (system to measure the annual stipend of a samurai with kokudaka) when mentioned for samurai (especially daimyo).

sen.j: 明治時代の地租改正まで続いた。
sen.e: Kokudaka system lasted until the land-tax reform in the Meiji period.
Kokudaka system lasted until the land-tax reform in the Meiji period.
Kokudaka system lasted until the land-tax reform in the Meiji period.

sen.j: 一石は大人一人が一年に食べる米の量に相当することから、これを兵士たちに与える報酬とみなせば、石高×年貢率と同じだけの兵士を養えることになる。
sen.e: 1 stone was equal to the amount of rice consumed by an adult man in a year, so if 1 stone of rice is equated with the reward for a soldier, the kokudaka multiplied by the rate of "nengu" (land-tax) implies the number of soldiers feeded.

1 koku was equal to the amount of rice consumed by an adult man in a year, so if 1 koku of rice is equated with the reward for a soldier, the kokudaka multiplied by the rate of nengu (land-tax) implies the number of soldiers fed.

1 koku was equal to the amount of rice consumed by an adult man in a year, so if 1 koku of rice is equated with the reward for a soldier, the kokudaka multiplied by the rate of nengu (land-tax) implies the number of soldiers fed.

sen.j: つまり石高は戦国大名の財力だけではなく兵力をも意味していた。
sen.e: In other words, kokudaka showed not only the financial power but also the troop strength of a warring lord.
In other words, kokudaka showed not only the financial power but also the troop strength of Sengoku daimyo (Japanese territorial lord in the Sengoku period).
sen.cmt: 統一リストに合わせました。
sen.e: In other words, kokudaka showed not only the financial power but also the troop strength of Sengoku daimyo (Japanese territorial lord in the Sengoku period).

sen.j: 江戸時代の軍役令によると、大名は幕府の命に応じて表高1万石あたり概ね2百人程度の軍勢（非戦闘員を含む）を動員する義務を課せられていた。
sen.e: The order of military service issued by bakufu in the Edo period enforced daimyo to mobilize about 200 people (including noncombatants) for every 10 thousand stones of "omote-daka" (kokudaka officially recognized by Edo bakufu).

The order of military service issued by bakufu in the Edo period enforced daimyo to mobilize about 200 people (including noncombatants) for every 10,000 koku of omote-daka (kokudaka officially recognized by the Edo bakufu).
sen.cmt: アラビア数字に用語を変更しました。
sen.e: The order of military service issued by bakufu in the Edo period enforced daimyo to mobilize about 200 people (including noncombatants) for every 10,000 koku of omote-daka (kokudaka officially recognized by the Edo bakufu).

sen.j: これらは、あくまで幕府公称の数字（表高）であり、実際の収穫高である内高とは、かなりの乖離がある藩も多い。
sen.e: The following is only the figure officially recognized by Edo bakufu (omote-daka) of local domains, and their "uchi-daka" (real figure of rice harvest) was quite different from their omote-daka in many cases.

The following is only the figure officially recognized by the Edo bakufu (omote-daka) of local domains, and their uchi-daka (real figure of rice harvest) was quite different from their omote-daka in many cases.

The following is only the figure officially recognized by the Edo bakufu (omote-daka) of local domains, and their uchi-daka (real figure of rice harvest) was quite different from their omote-daka in many cases.

sen.j: 詳細は内高を参照のこと。
sen.e: For details, please refer to the section of "Uchi-daka."
For details, please refer to the article of Uchi-daka.
sen.cmt: 統一リストに合わせました。
sen.e: For details, please refer to the article of Uchi-daka.

The figure as of the last days of the Tokugawa shogunate

sen.j: 別格：江戸幕府徳川将軍家
sen.e: The special status family : The Tokugawa Shogun family in control of Edo bakufu
The special status family: The Tokugawa Shogun family in control of the Edo bakufu
The special status family: The Tokugawa Shogun family in control of the Edo bakufu

sen.j: - 飛騨国や甲斐国など天領400万石。
sen.e: 4 million stones of "tenryo" (bakufu-owned land), including Hida Province and Kai Province
4 million koku of tenryo (bakufu-owned land), including Hida Province and Kai Province.
4 million koku of tenryo (bakufu-owned land), including Hida Province and Kai Province.

sen.j: （この数字に知行所を持つ旗本・交代寄合の石高300万石は含まれない）。
sen.e: : This figure does not include 3 million stones of kokudaka, gained from the fiefs of hatamoto, including "kotai-yoriai" (the hatamoto which had alternate-year residence in Edo).
sen.cmt: （注）「交代寄合」とは「参勤交代を行う旗本」の意味です。
sen.e: (This figure does not include 3 million koku of kokudaka, gained from the fiefs of hatamoto, including kotai-yoriai (the hatamoto which had alternate-year residence in Edo).

sen.j: 加賀国,能登国,越中国の3国の大半を領有。
sen.e: It ruled Kaga Province, Noto Province, and most of Ecchu Province;
